reviewText:
The last game in the fantastic Prince of Persia trilogy. This time, the game changes radically. Again.

The new gameplay now includes elements of stealth and the ability to do more damage without being seen or heard. Exploration and making progress through climbing, swinging, jumping, sliding and wall-running are still a huge part of the game, which is awesome. They even added some chariot levels. But the biggest change and probably the most important is the appearance of the Prince's alter ego.

The Dark Prince is manifested by an internal voice that speaks to the Prince... at first. The Dark Prince is cold, cruel, arrogant, and sarcastic, and attempts to convince the Prince that they are the same person, and that the Prince should strive to serve only himself, using the Prince's vengeance as a catalyst for his other emotions. On many occasions, the Dark Prince seizes control of the Prince's body and the Prince is fully transformed into a kind of hybrid sand monster with abilities that allow the Prince to pass otherwise insurmountable obstacles.

While searching for the Vizier, the Prince encounters Farah, who does not remember him, and is surprised that the Prince knows her name. Despite this, the pair begin to grow an entirely new romance together.

Yuri Lowenthal's soothing voice is back. The Prince would not be the same without it. Beautiful monologues scattered through-out the game make it so much more enjoyable. The music is having Persian influences, but is much more epic than Sands of Time. Epic as in a theme of grandeur and heroism. Majestic and impressively great moment that you are experiencing, with lots of well-done cliffhangers. I still like the original more than everything.

Some of the characters are familiar to the player, others are new and provocative. But with no doubt, both look unique and interesting. The Prince changes his appearance several times, as the corruption keeps getting further. And eventually transforming into the Dark Prince. Besides that there are a lot of weapons, secrets, and other hidden items.

The game looks fantastic, as it shows you the very roofs of Babylon and then down into the depths of the city's dry well.

As well as the Warrior Within, this game has a secret ending. The good ending requires a bit more effort, but it's totaly worth it.

Solid gameplay, amazing music and voice-acting, great and intruguing storyline, with lots of plot twists, and nice looks. The last part of this trilogy really mixed all of the best from the previous games. Thus creating an incredible game that feels great.



10/10

reviewText: Ahh Prince of Persia. Assassins Creed's older acrobatic brother. This game is great. Youve got combos, sick acrobatic puzzles, and time control. TIME CONTROL! Wanna cheat death by rewinding time to get out of a bottemless pit? easy. messed up a stealth kill on an eenmy and wanna second chance? hit that R button. there are some annoying points though. Some of the jump puzzles are devious. But overall, this game is definatly worth a playthrough. dont even mind the crap graphics, about 5 minutes in, u wont even notice. and besides, its better to have a great game with crappy graphics *cough, zelda, cough*, then a 1080p game that sucks ♥♥♥. *cough, COD Ghosts, cough*. So go pick it up and get your prince on.

reviewText:
This was a huge favorite of mine back when it was originally released, so in spite of my reservations about haphazard ports, I was happy when this unadulterated version was released on Steam. As far as I could tell, it seems to be a pretty direct copy of the original. The graphics have been touched up a bit, but the gameplay, content, menus, and music all remain the same as they were a decade ago. Steam has this tagged as “partial controller support”, but aside from a few things on the menu, the whole game is controller friendly.

How does the actual gaming experience hold up, though? The graphics are outdated, Ubisoft has moved on to bigger and bolder things with the Assassin’s Creed series, and many avid fans of our favorite wall-running protagonist would tell you to just stick with 2003’s seminal Sands of Time if you want the true POP experience. So what makes Two Thrones worth playing a decade later?

There are a number of less important factors I could point to. The music is crisp, regionally appropriate (thank God), and diverse. The voice acting harkens back to the more subtle days of Sands of Time, and the schizophrenic conversations between the Prince and his dark alter-ego are funny, illuminating, and cleverly deployed in support of the game’s overall narrative. The boss battles are varied, make clever use of the game’s mechanics, and, particularly in the case of the final two fights, are truly epic in a way that was often missing in previous series installments. The game is linear, but within that linear construct, it offers you multiple ways to accomplish your objectives. And that brings us to the true strength of this game:

Two words: visceral satisfaction. In other words, the quick-kill system. It sounds odd to say that a repetitive system of QTEs positively defines a game, but it isn’t the physical act of button-pressing that makes this mechanism tick; it’s how you get there. In Two Thrones, there are basically three options for combat. You can avoid large parts of it by just platforming past enemies and keeping your eyes on the prize. You can cover yourself in the blood and sands of your enemies by flinging yourself headfirst into combat,  where you can breakdance, roll, and slash your way to gruesome victory by means of the same combat system from Warrior Within. The final option, though, is the most satisfying, and the most clever from a game design standpoint. In Sands of Time, platforming and combat were kept largely segregated, and combat was just something you reluctantly waded through so you could get back to traversing the gorgeous landscapes. In Warrior Within, you were still frequently forced into prolonged moments of repetitive hacking, albeit with a mechanically improved combat system. In Two Thrones, however, platforming and combat are finally integrated, and dear lord are they integrated effectively. Instead of just serving as the means to getting from point A to point B, platforming is now also deployed as a way to get the jump on your foes. Instead of waltzing in daggers drawn, you can now climb above, around, and past your enemies in order to sneak up behind them, hear some satisfying middle eastern beats, and quickly dispose of them with some brutally efficient killing strokes. It’s difficult to overstate how satisfying this mechanic is. You will seldom feel like more of a badass than when you’ve executed a series of precise quick-kills to silently eliminate a group of enemies. I found myself replaying parts of the game just to determine how best to utilize the environment to surprise my unsuspecting sand monster friends. That thrill, that desire to maximize the glorious synthesis between your dagger strokes and your gravity-defying stunts, is what drives this game, as well as what keeps you coming back.

reviewText:
what it could have been and what is

Kindred Blades could have been the wanted continuation of Warrior Within, instead we have The Two Thrones

while TTT is an excellent game it's a wrap up of the Sands of Time which I found out to be somewhat a let down, it backed out form some of the most interesting concepts from Warrior within:

- it's again a linear game instead of the open space that Warrior Within had
- there is only one ending instead of the two from WW
- the grittiness of WW is gone, and we're back to SOT graphical style
- the story is simple

there are some bonus though:

- there is some more variety in the level design.
- there is a somewhat kind of stealth, which is optional, and allows for some non linear gameplay, so you're not forced into the stealth.
- charriot races, are cool but there are too few of them.
- arab-like music again. much better than the rock from WW.
- again two principes (like the sandwraith from WW)
- interesting boss battles (although one of them is hard as f**k)

it's interesting how this POP it's a middle ground inbetween the POP franchise and the first Assassin's Creed game, AC it's clearly a spiritual succesor from TTT

best to be played with gamepad

the game is completely enjoyable, play it you won't regret it.

reviewText:
Prince of Persia: The Two Thrones is the third and LAST game of the sands trilogy (do never play The Forgotten Sands). It begins exactly where Warrior Within ends, so I recommend you to play, not only WW, but also The Sands of Time, because of the strong storyline connection.

While the first two games of this trilogy are a wonderful masterpiece from the very first second to the end, in TT we experience a quiet slow and weak beginning, mostly because of the sloppy fights and small, uninspired scenarios.

But the game will get stronger and more interesting soon, by adding brand new concepts and systems to the PoP series, like a satisfying stealth combat system, some funny chariot races, new platforming elements, and, what's more important, the dark prince as a playable character.

As the dark prince, you will have more strength, more powers, new platforming abilities... It helps to make the game much deeper. Add this to great boss fights, excellente puzzles, some beautiful scenarios plus a full controller compatibility and 1080p resolution, and you have a HUGE game, with an epic and unforgettable finale.

reviewText:
Probably the most enjoyable game in the PoP trilogy. It doesn't have as much combat as the first two and it allows you to avoid a lot of it with the newly added stealth kills. It mixes things up every once in a while with the chariot sections and the Dark Prince sections.

This game has a weird place in the trilogy. Sands of Time had the most puzzles and Warrior Within had the most involved platforming sections, but this game doesn't really have much of either. It's a bit of a weird one in that sense because it's definitely the most enjoyable of the three, but it's the easiest and--mechanically speaking--it's the least interesting.

Still a very good game, though.

Update: I had an issue when I was unable to slide down the chain with the Prince. This issues can be fixed by enabling V-sync setting form the option menu. After enabling that setting, you ought not have any more problems sliding down the chains.

The visuals show the age of the game but the gaming experince is still good. The dialog is not great and the hero's voice is a bit annoying at times. Overall, I am enjoying the game.

The game is buggy for WIndows 8. I am stuck at a stage where I cannot slide down a chain. Earlier in the game when the character runs along the wall, he just falls; I had to quit the game and start fresh to rectify the problem.  The camera angles are terrible but it is tolerable. This game is not playble for me until I have a patch for this game. Be careful downloading old games.

reviewText:
Prince Of Persia The Two Thrones is a Action-Adventure Following the Closing of are Prince and his Battle against Vizier.The Gameplay in The Two Thrones,unlike Previous installments has you Driving Chariots in fast-paced action to get to locations,also,a main selling point,Transforming at points of the Game as The Dark Prince,Wielding TheDaggerOfTime in his Right hand,and a Chain in his left that he can Swing,Choke,latch,and Manuever with.TheStandardPrince is the same in combat,with the exception of StealthKills and hardly noticable New sand powers,with the exception of the Standard,Slow,Fast,and Stopping of time.Aside from The Bad Saving,it's a Solid Entry and a must for the Fans of the Series.The Story Starts Right where TheWarriorWithin left off,with The Prince Returning Home with his Love Kaileena,only to find his boat attacked,his City in War,and his Throne taken over by the Vizier.

reviewText: It turns out tampering with the timeline is not so good as it sounds on the paper. On his way home, the Prince was welcomed by a surprise party from India who decided the best present ever would be to take his loved Empress and turn it into the Sands of Time. After the extensive exposure to the magical sand and the vessel of the sand (He did knew Kaileena if you know what I mean), He got a bit schizophrenic, developing his darker alter ego, the Dark Prince. Go figure.\nA fine conclusion to the trilogy that left the throne to the assassains.

reviewText:
Almost everything in this game screams about a bad console port.

The bad technical things:
1) game doesn't start when run from Steam, you have to make the direct shortcut to PrinceOfPersia.exe and enable compatibility mode
2) even then it starts only every other time
3) sometimes the game infinitely loads a save and then silently crashes after some time
4) Windows Media Center starts after closing the game
5) often game doesn't respond to standard key sequences like Alt+Tab, Win+D etc. and always tries to restore itself to fullscreen state when minimized

The annoying gameplay things:
1) unskippable cutscenes
2) weird camera movements - it auto-rotates according to the character movements(WASD) and ignores mouse movements, so you can't run AND look around at the same time
3) in every menu cursor just jumps to the item that is most appropriate in developers' opinion. WTF, it's MY mouse and MY cursor, I decide where to move it!
4) the landscape view is now available only at predefined locations - no more admiring the environment for you, player

However, the story is worth it. Definitely get this game if you're a SoT fan and/or played previous games.

P.S. The best thing about old games - none of that online/Uplay BS.

reviewText: Masterpiece. Classic. <Insert other usless cliche here>\nThis is the pinnacle of the action platformer (My love for this series keeps me from replacing assassin's creed as the pinnacle of action platformers, because really, it's a completely different type of game, and I love them both). No arguements. The final chapter in our nameless hero's journey is an epic one, and has very few faults. A truely outstanding game. Prince of Persia holds a very special place in my heart, I knew the first 2 minutes that I played the Sands of Time that I had discovered something truely remarkable, and the feeling lasted all the way till the final game. It deals with far more diverse topics then the previous two games, among them, the darker parts of the prince's personality. And the story is top-notch, a quality I've come to associate with Ubisoft games. This series is not one you should miss out on.

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings about this installment of Prince of Persia.  I read several reviews online that gave glowing reviews of this sequel and said that it was far better than Warrior Within.  I completely disagree.  If you've played through Sands of Time and Warrior Within, then of course you should buy this game and see how the story ends.  But I finished the game feeling dissatisfied.

The game offers two major improvements over Warrior Within:  the speed-kill system and a better atmosphere.  The speed-kill system lets you dispatch enemies from stealth, like an assassin.  I guess it was pretty cutting edge back in 2005, but I didn't feel the magic.  Sure, it opens up an entirely new play style, but it takes some trial-and-error to get the timing right.  This killed the mood for me.  What's the point of a cool, cinematic fight sequence if I have to keep retrying it because I missed the timing on a single click of the mouse?  I didn't master the speed-kill system until about halfway through the game, and by that point it had lost its appeal.  My verdict:  the speed-kill system is great on your second play through, but be prepared to invest some practice before you can pull it off consistently.

I won't say too much about the atmosphere, except that it's an improvement.  The designers set the game in Babylon and got rid of the gothic Warrior Within vibe.  So that's a plus.  Oh, and there are some very cool battles where you can fight with chains.

So what about the problems?  Well, there are several.  To avoid spoiling anything, I'll just mention that the prince has a certain dark companion" in this installment.  Their dialogue is meant to be a witty banter but it really falls flat.  The "dark companion" dialogues are cheesy and his voice sounds whiny rather than menacing.

My major annoyance has to do with the boss battles.  In my opinion
date: what made earlier installments of Prince of Persia so great was their level design.  A reasonably skilled player could fight through entire levels and puzzles without having to reload constantly.  Sure
recommended: there were a few mindbending challenges
hoursPlayed: but generally the games were high-paced and exciting.  Warrior Within is the perfect example of this:  the Dahaka chases were fast-paced races that kept you on your toes and that rewarded quick-thinking.  You didn't have to practice over and over again just to succeed on a Dahaka chase sequence.\n\nTwo Thrones is just the opposite.  Most of the bosses can only be killed if you know the specific trick sequence necessary to finish them off.  For almost all of the bosses
voteText: there is no way you will figure out the trick on your first try.  The boss battles completely kill the pacing of the game because you have to stop and figure out the specific trick you have to use to get through the challenge.  It's not at all appropriate for a high-speed adventure game series like Prince of Persia.  Also
helpfulPercent: just because you've played through the first two games without any trouble does not mean you'll be ready for this third game.  I spent the first 25% of the game just learning the new timing and figuring out the new sets.\n\nTo sum up:  Two Thrones has a cool speed-kill system and a better atmosphere than Warrior Within.  These features are great for your second and third playthroughs
votesHelpful: because by that point you'll know the game's tricks and you'll be able to play it at an exciting
votesTotal: high speed.  But otherwise it's a definite downgrade from Warrior Within.  Sands of Time and Warrior Within are still fun to play in 2015 (and great bargains these days)--Two Thrones just kind of sucks.  But you should play it anyway if you've already been through Sands of Time and Warrior Within
votesFunny: because that way you can see how the story ends."

reviewText:
Before I started playing PoP:TTT, I thought I'd hate it. I'd previously played both Sands of Time and Warrior Within, the latter of which I particularly disliked, and also the first Assassin's Creed game. So I've had enough experience with these Ubisoft action-adventure games to be able to say I don't like them.

Perhaps this is why I chose to play the game on Easy, but whatever the reason, it was the right choice; it made the bad parts tolerable and left the good parts untouched. And there really are some genuinely good parts. No, fantastic parts, to the game. And all of them are in the form of the parkour-style climbing, which on it's own makes the Sands of Time trilogy an important milestone in platforming games.

Conversely, the fluff that pads the game out is the combat; understandably dated, but none-the-less dull as drokk. The problem's not that it's too simple, but that it takes so damn long and as I said, I was playing on Easy, so I dread to think what it's like at the harder difficulties.

Ultimately, the reason I can't recommend this game is because of a glitch on The Middle Tower level (the penultimate one, no less). Right near the end of the section there's one of the springboards that flings you 45 degrees, in this case towards a knife pad. For whatever reason, no matter how many times I tried, I landed to the right of the knife pad, about two feet out of reach. I'd exhausted all my sand tanks three times before I called it quits, if it was nearer the checkpoint it wouldn't be such a big deal, but I was having to repeat the same combat sequences each time and that was really the nail in the coffin for me.

reviewText: i'm a massive fan of the prince of persia series. i have been since i played the original long long ago. having said that, this game is awful on pc. the story, and the voice acting are both wonderful, and hell, even by my standards, the graphics are okay, but good god are the controls awful. especially on mouse and keyboard. moving the camera around is slow, which makes climbing around extremely difficult, because usually you have to look around to see the proper path, and speaking of climbing, the movements are clunky and unresponsive, or the prince just does the wrong thing alltogether. i've tried playing with a contoller, but that makes barely any difference. moving the camera gets slightly easier, but that's about all it does. all in all, that's what killed it for me. if you really want to buy the game, go ahead, but be warned, it's frustrating. if youre only interested in the story, however, you can do what i did, and go watch someone else play it on youtube.

reviewText:
I won't touch on gameplay and story in this review as the PC version did its best to demotivate me from playing it.

First of all, the mouse control is terrible -- the faster you move your mouse, the slower the camera moves and vice versa. An example: If I move my mouse switftly over my mousepad, the change of angles is about 160°, but when I do so more slowly, then the camera rotates several times, which I feel is completely unnatural. On the other hand, the game tries to figure out what you want to look at (I suppose), so you also get stuck and mouse movements are being ignored. Settings to significantly improve upon this situation are non-existent.

The second issue I had was that at several points in the game white/yellow blobs exploded on my screen, soon making it completely white or yellow. Certainly not intended to happen as alt-tabbing in and out clears this temporarily. I use Windows 7 and a GeForce GTX 650 Ti and tried suggestion to disable fog and vsync as well as to change the compatibility mode of the binary, neither of which helped.

tldr; Not recommended for keyboard+mouse users with low frustration threshold. As an aged game this might not work well on every modern PC.

reviewText: Seems as though they learned from their primary mistakes in Warrior Within, some of the charm of Sands of Time have returned. The hero is less brooding and lame, the heroines are less there for eye candy, the tangled mess of an open world is gone, and a greater focus on combat while still there has been tweaked and rebalanced to have some better stealth elements. Camera and controls are still pretty bad, and the addition of a new form that is both necessary to complete hazards and cost health is a really annoying design choice. While it there are many things better about it than Warrior Within, I still cannot recommend it.

reviewText:
For the price, I might otherwise say that this game is worth it; but it happens to be riddled with serious bugs that have ultimately rendered it unplayable. The plotline is fairly weak, the references to earlier games are thick, and I repeatedly run into serious physics errors.

What attracted me to The Sands of Time (a better choice) was the lengthy sequences of dynamic acrobatic puzzles; you don't really get as many of those in this one. There's a lot more combat, and in all honesty the combat system has never been the strong suit for PoP.

When it's only a couple of bucks, it might be worth it; but Ubisoft has done nothing about these bugs as of yet and provides no hints that it is ever going to.

reviewText: Prince of Persia: The Two Thrones is the most well-balanced in the trilogy for all visual, gameplay and story. voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
In the context of the series this is a very dissapointing third act, but a solid game on it's own. The game was really short and rushed. The story and dialogue were poorly written  and inconsistent. Rather than tweak and enhance the formula that has been established in the previous two game this game chooses to do the opposite. The mulitple endings in the previous game have been ditched for a single one. The nonlinear play style has also been ditched. The new 'Speed Kill' mechanic is annoying and I found it to be rather hit and miss for me. I was contantly rewinding because I missed my window. This was even more infuriating during the boss fights when I was the only way to defeat the enemy.
Using speed kill as the dark prince was much more satifiiying. It felt more stealthy and was just easier overall. I really like playing as the dark prince, the change in fighting stlye was nice, but it felt unpolished. I hated the banter between the prince and the dark prince. It was so annoying and after dieing/rewinding and having to hear it over and over again, i just ended up putting it on mute. And I never really understood where the dark prince came from. Was he a side effect of the sands, or something left over from sand wraith?
I didn't like how the game forced you to use the dark prince only during certain times. It would be cool if you could choose and depending on how much you use him or for what events it triggers differnt alternative plot lines and areas on the map. Say if you defeated the Vizier as the Dark prince you would trigger the bad end and would simply take the vizier's place and a sand god.
Overall this game is not as sophisticated as it's predecessor. I do not mind the lightening of the tone and color pallette but it would be nice if that came about because of your actions in game.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Probably the best game out of the Sands of Time trilogy, the epic timetravel storyline intertwining all games comes to an end.

It mixes the previous games flawlessly. It doesn't have as much combat as Warrior Within but when it does you get to fight as the Dark Prince, and there's multiple fun boss battles which adds some spice to the recipe. I think it has the perfect balance between puzzles from the first game and combat from the second. It brings all the great aspects of both previous games to the table.

Puzzles are probably the most fun in the trilogy, the level design and environments are ♥♥♥♥ing great, the new parkour mechanics are cool as well and serve as a great compliment to the already established parkour system from the previous games. The soundtrack is also top notch in these series as always.

The story picks up right where Warrior Within left off and we get to see a less edgy prince who wants to make up for his mistakes. There's an immediate connection with the first game with the return of the original voice actor and the constant conversations between characters and head narration just like Sands of Time, there's never a dull moment thanks to the random serious or funny interactions and it feels much more personal. If there was one thing about Warrior Within that I didn't like was the absence of narration and the only conversations you'd get would be in cutscenes. Even though the game is a direct sequel to Warrior WIthin storywise if feels much more like what Sands of Time 2 would look like.

Overall, a great sequel and end to a trilogy. Ubisoft used to be pretty good huh?

reviewText: Third installment of the Sands of Time trilogy, although the penulimate of the storyline. Very good game.  It is considerably shorter than the previous two games. Some pretty interesting new fighting styles introduced here that I think made the game better (more challenging) but also easier if you're completely comfortable with it. All in all, great game.\n\n7.5/10
